top_categories.workout_context: Heck of the North’s snowmobile trails (roots, rocks), minnesota northwoods forest roads demands rapid power changes — surge over obstacles, settle on smoother sections, repeat for hours.
Racing Heck of the North isn’t just fitness — it’s pacing, fueling, and executing when conditions deteriorate. This workout practices the race itself.
At 100 miles, Heck of the North punishes athletes who haven’t trained their body to produce power when glycogen runs low.
Heck of the North rewards athletes who can hold sustained power without blowing up — threshold is the engine that drives everything above Zone 2.
Critical power determines how long you can sustain above-threshold efforts at Heck of the North — a higher CP means more time in the red before failure.
The G-Spot zone (88–92% FTP) is where you’ll spend the hardest sustained miles of Heck of the North. Make this intensity feel like home.
Over-unders train the lactate clearance you’ll need at Heck of the North when surges push you above threshold and you have to recover while still riding hard.
Heck of the North’s technical snowmobile-trail gravel and competitive field demand explosive aerobic capacity — the ability to respond to surges without blowing up.
Short, violent efforts are unavoidable at Heck of the North — climbs demanding 2-minute maximal efforts, surges to close gaps, attacks on technical snowmobile-trail gravel.
Cadence efficiency makes every pedal stroke at Heck of the North count — smooth technique reduces muscular fatigue over long distances.
Blended sessions combine endurance with intensity spikes — exactly what Heck of the North’s technical snowmobile-trail gravel delivers on race day.
The Norwegian double-threshold method builds the sustained power base for Heck of the North — massive training stimulus without the recovery cost of VO2max work.

race_overlay.nutrition: Target 60–80g carbs/hour for Heck of the North’s 100 miles. Start fueling within the first 30 minutes — early fueling prevents late-race collapse. Bonking at mile 60 is a nutrition failure, not a fitness failure.
race_overlay.terrain: Highly technical terrain at Heck of the North demands practice on similar surfaces. Ride technical snowmobile-trail gravel at race-day cadence weekly. Expect: snowmobile trails (roots, rocks), minnesota northwoods forest roads, technical singletrack-width paths. Practice cornering, descending, and power delivery on unstable surfaces. Dial in tire pressure before race week — 5 PSI wrong costs you 15+ minutes over 100 miles.

pack_summary: This 10-workout pack focuses on Gravel Specific, Race Simulation, and Durability to prepare you for 100 miles of technical snowmobile-trail gravel in Two Harbors, Minnesota.
